summary: In Nartey v Mechanical Lloyd Assembly Plant Ltd, the Supreme Court of Ghana addressed a dispute over La rural land in Frafraha, focusing on whether a sub-stool (Agbawe family) could validly grant land or if such authority rested solely with the La stool. The plaintiff claimed title via a 1976 grant from the Mantse of Frafraha (OK), while the defendant relied on a 1979 grant from the same source and an earlier 1976 lease to a private individual. The Court split: Taylor and Wuaku JJSC held that sub-stool grants are ineffective unless the La stool is estopped by acquiescence; Adade JSC believed sub-stools generally have granting power; the dissenters viewed all such grants as invalid. The majority found for the plaintiff based on his prior possession and the defendant's failure to prove superior title. The case clarified that trespass actions depend on possession, not title, and affirmed the relevance of estoppel by acquiescence where customary practice contradicts formal legal rules.
verdict: Plaintiff's appeal was upheld by the Supreme Court majority.
citations: Nartey v Mechanical Lloyd Assembly Plant Ltd
Nii Adjei Onano v Okoi Noi
rationaleHighlights: Grant by sub-stool may be valid if La stool acquiesced
Possession, not title, is key in trespass actions
Estoppel by acquiescence applied to land grants
Customary practice can inform legal rights despite prior judicial rulings
Plaintiff must prove possession, not title, initially
Defendant's weaker title does not automatically benefit plaintiff
